Award.AwardTitle: Spaces of Rational Curves in Projective Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The projects described in this proposal aim to contribute towards understanding moduli spaces of rational curves on complete intersections. The study of rational curves on smooth complete intersections is fundamental to a broad spectrum of important problems about Fano varieties, rationally connected varieties, and diophantine geometry. Despite some progress over the past few years, some of the basic properties of these spaces are still unknown. In the proposed research, some open questions on the dimension, irreducibility, Kodaira dimension, and several other aspects of the geometry of spaces of rational curves on complete intersections in projective space and other homogeneous varieties are investigated.


Algebraic varieties are common zeros of collections of polynomial equations. An important approach to study the geometry of algebraic varieties is to study parameter spaces of rational curves contained in them. These parameter spaces are themselves varieties with rich geometry, and in the case of hypersurfaces, the study of them has broad applications in higher dimensional algebraic geometry, modern enumerative geometry, and questions inspired by mirror symmetry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important approach to the study of the geometry of algebraic varieties is to understand rational curves contained in them. The results obtained over the period of this award contribute towards understanding some geometric aspects of the parameter space of rational curves on algebraic varieties in particular hypersurfaces of low degree in projective space. This includes results on the birational geometry of moduli spaces of rational curves on general Fano hypersurfaces, rational surfaces in hypersurfaces of low degree, and moduli spaces of rational curves on special smooth Fano hypersurfaces. The broader impact of this research spans several different areas and is fundamental to a broad spectrum of important problems in diophantine geometry, modern enumerative geometry, the study of Gromov-Witten invariants of varieteis, and quesitons inspired by mirror symmetry.

Beheshti has advised a graduate student and a postdoc over the period of this grant. She has presented her research in various local and international seminars and conferences, and has been active giving talks in the existing outreach programs at Washington University. She has co-organized the algebraic geometry seminar at Washington University as well as several workshops and AMS special sessions. She has also taught various graduate and undergraduate courses in algebraic geometry.
